page.title: 03VILLAGE HOMES
page.content: Coverack has some two-hundred houses and bungalows; many of them homes for people who have chosen to retire to the village. Some forty houses are not lived in for nine months of the year. These houses are second homes for people living in other parts of the country, or whose owners rent them out during the summer season as holiday homes. This gives rise to some concern amongst local people, for there is little prospect that planning approval would be given for building more homes, and house prices are inflated by reason of the popularity of the area. The young people of the village, after marrying, have slight chance of continuing to live in the area in which they were born. The age of the population is increasing as gradually the young men and women move out to seek work and homes elsewhere.
